acts.name: IP spoofing
acts.desc: Send packages with the faked IP address. Counter those techniques based on IP addresses.

acts.name: ARP cache poisoning
acts.desc: Send fake arp response to fool the victim. Can be used to perform MITM attack. Defended by ARP firewall.

acts.name: Rogue access point
acts.desc: Set up a fake access point and lure the vicitms to connect. The first step towards MITM attack.

acts.name: Rogue DHCP server
acts.desc: with also rogue DHCP server on it. default gateway and DNS set as the attackers.

acts.name: Rogue DNS server
acts.desc: Use a fake DNS server to reply to victim's DNS request wrongly. Lure the victim to the attacker's websites.

acts.name: DNS cache poisoning
acts.desc: Spead out wrong DNS response to poison the cache of hosts and DNS servers of a large area. Lure the victim to the attacker's websites.

acts.name: XSS
acts.desc: One type of session hijacking or cookie hijacking. Run unexpected javascript code to send cookies to the attacker's server. Penetrate same-origin policy

acts.name: CSRF
acts.desc: An attack to forge client request without the consents of the client. Can be thwarted by Tip:open no unauthorized link.

acts.name: Tip:open no unauthorized link
acts.desc: A principle to thwart attacks like CSRF.

acts.name: ARP firewall
acts.desc: an firewall to fight against ARP cache poisioning.

acts.name: Tip:cautious for free wifi
acts.desc: A principle to fight Rogue access point.

acts.name: DHCP snooping
acts.desc: A group of defensive technique to protect the DHCP service.

acts.name: Manual DNS setting
acts.desc: To manually configure DNS mappings on each machines in the network. Provide some protection against Rogue DNS server. IP-based technique.

acts.name: Cookie bind to IP
acts.desc: Bind the cookies to the IP address, so that attackers who have stolen other's cookies can not easily use the cookie for impersonation. IP-based technique.

acts.name: HTTP-only cookie
acts.desc: Preventing the cookie to be sent by client APIs. Counters XSS.

acts.name: Secure cookie
acts.desc: Enforces the cookie to be sent only over secure connection. Counters XSS.

acts.name: DNSSEC
acts.desc: The secure version(using certificates) of DNS. Counters attacks on DNS.

buffs.name: Same-Origin policy
buffs.desc: An important concept in security for web applications. Scripts cannot refer to data from other origin. However, some offensive techniques like XSS and CSRF can by pass same-origin policy.

buffs.name: Tip:open no unauthorized link
buffs.desc: A principle to thwart attacks like CSRF.

buffs.name: ARP firewall
buffs.desc: an firewall to fight against ARP cache poisioning.

buffs.name: Connected to rogue AP
buffs.desc: The client is connected to rogue access point. The attacker can perform further attack to achieve MITM.

buffs.name: DHCP hijacked
buffs.desc: The victim has fallen to rogue DHCP server. Building a Rogue DNS server can trap the victim further.

buffs.name: DNS hijacked
buffs.desc: The victim has fallen to rogue DNS server. An XSS attack can be launched against the victim.

buffs.name: DHCP snooping
buffs.desc: An DHCP snooping can block Rogue DHCP server.

buffs.name: Manual DNS setting
buffs.desc: By manually setting the IP address of the DNS server, the clients will turn blind eyes to the fake DNS replies from rogue DNS servers. However, IP spoofing is possible to fool them.

buffs.name: Tip:cautious for free wifi
buffs.desc: With the client's awareness, rogue access point will not be effective.

buffs.name: DNSSEC
buffs.desc: with DNSSEC, all the attacks on DNS will fail.

buffs.name: Cookie bind to IP
buffs.desc: Cookie is bind to the IP address. Cookies stolen from victims of different IP address cannot be used. However, as an IP related technique, it can be fooled by IP spoofing.

buffs.name: HTTP-only cookie
buffs.desc: The cookies will not be sent by client APIs. XSS will fail.

buffs.name: Secure cookie
buffs.desc: The cookies will be sent only over secure connection. XSS will fail.

dialogues.name: Zack
dialogues.dialogue:
We have discovered a new form of attack called CSRF (Cross-Site Request Forgery)!
You now have an alternative path when XSS attack is blocked.

dialogues.name: Hank
dialogues.dialogue: Damn this! People begin to apply DNSSEC! If ArtificialCore also applies DNSSEC, our attack on the DNS service will be much harder.
